channel.title: NYT > Fashion & Style
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Is Stan Lee Being Held Prisoner by Real-Life Villains?
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.description: The Hollywood Reporter published an investigation saying that Mr. Lee, 95, was the victim of elder abuse. We visited the Marvel Comics creator at his home. “Nobody has more freedom,” he said.
item.dc:creator: BEN WIDDICOMBE

item.title: Modern Love: When Love Seems Too Easy to Trust
item.description: A young woman thought true love would have all the anxiety and insecurity of a romantic comedy. When it didn’t, that was even more worrisome.
item.dc:creator: ALI ELKIN

item.title: love is ...: The Museum of ‘Please Find Me’
item.description: The Lost & Found at Kennedy Airport is the last, best hope for travelers missing their iPads, meaningful snapshots and many, many wedding rings.
item.dc:creator: MAUD CASEY

item.title: The Dress Doctor Is In
item.description: Dawnn Karen of the Fashion Institute of Technology is a leader in the growing field of fashion psychology — or why we want what we think we want.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER MILLER

item.title: News Analysis: ‘Our Bodies, Ourselves’? It’s Shelved
item.media:description: An early cover of the women’s health book “Our Bodies, Ourselves,” published by the Boston Women’s Health Book Collective.
item.description: This book changed lives for decades. How will we know our bodies are normal now?
item.dc:creator: JESSICA VALENTI

item.title: Social Q’s: R.I.P. My Whole Family
item.description: Burying grief and anger by denying your family’s existence isn’t a long-term solution, our columnist writes.
item.dc:creator: PHILIP GALANES

item.title: Dress Designers Add Options for Plus-Size Brides
item.media:description: Josefina Rodriguez tries on a gown by the designer Justin Alexander at a recent bridal show at RK Bridal in Manhattan. The dresses were created especially for curvy women, sizes 18 to 32.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times
item.description: After years of being ignored, curvy brides are now finding more choices in wedding dresses as new fashion lines are rolling out.
item.dc:creator: ALIX STRAUSS

item.title: Yesterday in Styles: Wait, New Jersey Was Once Not Cool?
item.description: For years a punch line to snooty New Yorkers, New Jersey came into its own as a cultural hub in the 1990s, thanks to Lauryn Hill, Kevin Smith and “The Sopranos.”
item.dc:creator: ALEX WILLIAMS

item.title: Vows: Homeless in Seattle, and Marrying Under the Overpass
item.media:description: Michelle Vestal and Bob J. Kitcheon, who live in a tent community, share a kiss under the freeway in Seattle, where they married on March 18. A volunteer who served as the maid of honor made the wedding cake.
item.media:credit: Annabel Clark for The New York Times
item.description: On the wedding day of Michelle Vestal and Bob J Kitcheon, Ms. Vestal had been clean from crack cocaine for 84 days. “I would never have done it if it wasn’t for him,” she said.
item.dc:creator: CANDICE PIRES

item.title: I Was Skeptical About Ecstatic Dance
item.media:description: Ecstatic Dance NYC is monthly dance party. The dance floor rules include no phones, no photos, no talking.
item.media:credit: Deidre Schoo for The New York Times
item.description: Maybe it was something about the phrase “free-form movement in a judgment-free space.”
item.dc:creator: ELLIE SHECHET

item.title: Modern Love: Modern Love Podcast: Jeffrey Bowyer-Chapman Reads ‘A Brother as Significant as Any Other’
item.description: This week, the “UnReal” star reads a story of familial love.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Love Is ...: 3 American Intimacies I Don’t Get
item.description: The author, a star of “Silicon Valley,” ponders some rituals he finds a little baffling.
item.dc:creator: JIMMY O. YANG

item.title: Love Is ...: The Anxiety That Binds
item.description: Managing uncertainty is a full-time job. But then again, so is marriage.
item.dc:creator: CARMEN MARIA MACHADO

item.title: Browsing: Who Said Fashion People Don’t Like Food?
item.description: Because they definitely love Dimes.
item.dc:creator: HAYLEY PHELAN

item.title: Mariah Carey Opens Up About Bipolar Disorder
item.media:description: Mariah Carey told People magazine that she had not previously disclosed the diagnosis because “I didn’t want to carry around the stigma of a lifelong disease that would define me and potentially end my career.”
item.description: The disclosure to People magazine marks one of the first instances in which a celebrity of Ms. Carey’s stature has acknowledged mental health issues.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Critical Shopper: At Marni, Shopping the Good Shop Lollipop
item.media:credit: Stefania Curto for The New York Times
item.description: Reconsidering a fashion stalwart with a fresh infusion of childlike wonder and playfulness.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW SCHNEIER

item.title: Lose Weight? No Way. Proud to Be a Bigger Bride.
item.media:description: Kelsey Miller, a plus-size bride, on her wedding day. “It’s popular to declare yourself ‘body positive’ and accepting of yourself, but the truth is: Bias is still very much out there.”
item.description: Plus-size brides fight for respect in a wedding industry they say is focused on the size 2s.
item.dc:creator: TAMMY La GORCE

item.title: Love Is ...: For Judy Collins, Marriage Is a Song of Many Verses
item.media:description: The wedding of Judy Collins, left, and Louis Nelson at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in New York City on April 16, 1996.
item.description: Ms. Collins, a.k.a. Sweet Judy Blue Eyes, and Louis Nelson have been together for 40 years — “very good for an old hippie,” she said.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN

item.title: An Inside Look at Your Favorite Dating Sites
item.description: What’s happening behind the scenes at the sites and apps you know and love and hate, along with a couple that may not be on your radar (or phone).
item.dc:creator: VALERIYA SAFRONOVA

item.title: Love Is ...: What Makes a Greeting Card Black?
item.description: For more than two decades, Hallmark has directly addressed black customers with its Mahogany collection, whose cards speak to a shared history.
item.dc:creator: CORD JEFFERSON

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s I’m Sorry Suit
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, the C.E.O. of Facebook, testifies inside the Hart Hearing Room in Washington.
item.description: The Facebook C.E.O. wore a suit and tie to testify before Congress instead of his usual gray T-shirt. Here’s why it mattered.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Greatest Suits Appearances
item.description: His trademark sartorial simplicity aside, Mark Zuckerberg knows how to dress in something other than a gray T-shirt or hoodie.

item.title: The Sweet Spot: Why Is the Greatest Love of All Also the Hardest?
item.description: A server, student and abuse survivor who longs to be a writer wonders why she is so supportive of her colleagues, but not herself.
item.dc:creator: STEVE ALMOND and CHERYL STRAYED

item.title: Spring Fashion: ’80s Irreverence Makes a Comeback
item.media:credit: Photograph by Tom Johnson. Styled by Malina Joseph Gilchrist
item.description: Today’s spin on the decade’s classics features wild faux fur, leather dresses, punk-rock ruffles and strong suiting.

item.title: The ‘Kanye West of Furniture’ Is Now Nesting in the ’Burbs
item.media:description: Franklin Getchell, left, and Murray Moss at their home in Hamden, Conn.
item.media:credit: Collin Hughes for The New York Times
item.description: For years Murray Moss ran one of SoHo’s toniest stores with his longtime partner, Franklin Getchell. The two men have written a memoir of fin-de-millennium excess (blowtorched Steinway, anyone?).
item.dc:creator: PENELOPE GREEN
item.category: Please Do Not Touch: And Other Things You Couldn't Do at Moss the Design Store That Changed Design (Book)

item.title: Up Next: She Makes Fancy Ice Cubes for a Living
item.media:description: Leslie Kirchhoff of Disco Cubes, at her home in Los Angeles.
item.media:credit: Kaleb Marshall for The New York Times
item.description: Leslie Kirchhoff is the founder of Disco Cubes, which elevates the lowly ice cube to an art form.
item.dc:creator: STACY SUAYA

item.title: Skin Deep: Why So Many Asian-American Women Are Bleaching Their Hair Blond
item.media:description: The fashion stylist and influencer Tina Leung.
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.description: In some salons, as many as half of the Asian-American clients are going lighter.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA CHENG

item.title: Profile in style: Back to the Early ’80s With Michael Kors
item.description: The celebrated designer first made his name four decades ago, in Manhattan. Here, he shares some of his many inspirations.
item.dc:creator: LINDSAY TALBOT

item.title: Imagining a World After Anna
item.media:description: Anna Wintour, in the receiving line at the Met Costume Gala in 2012, including, from left, Donald Trump, Melania Trump, Barry Diller, Miuccia Prada, Diane Von Furstenberg and Carey Mulligan.
item.media:credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times
item.description: A rumor that Anna Wintour was leaving Vogue spread like wildfire. Condé Nast says it’s not true. But what would that look like and why all the chatter?
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: ‘A Culture Free of Sexual Violence’
item.description: Each generation, Antioch College pushes the culture forward. First America laughs — then it follows.

item.title: Alicia Ortega, Debraj Mukherjee
item.description: The couple met in 2012 at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.

item.title: Tiffany Peng, Jason Hwa
item.description: The couple met two years ago through OkCupid; they married at the Bronx Zoo.

item.title: Rebecca Stump, Justin Werner II
item.description: The couple met on a blind date in Manhattan in April 2011; they were married in the Massachusetts Berkshires.

item.title: Grace Chapin, Jason James
item.description: Grace Chapin and Jason James met through OkCupid while she was on a business trip in China. They saw each other for the first time via Skype.

item.title: Susan Edwards, Pete Strom
item.description: The bride and groom, both lawyers, were married at their home in Columbia, S.C.

item.title: Eric Chow, Christopher Chambers
item.description: Mr. Chow is a doctor. Mr. Chambers is a master diver. They met on OkCupid.

item.title: Lindsey Pearl, Leah Rubin-Cadrain
item.description: Lindsay Pearl and Leah Rubin-Cadrain were married April 7 at Caravan Outpost, an Airstream trailer hotel in Ojai, Calif.

item.title: Constance Carter, Gordon Dale
item.description: The couple married at the Sulgrave Club in Washington.

item.title: Priya Prasad, James Bowe III
item.media:description: The couple met while working together in interest rate sales at Morgan Stanley in New York in 2011.
item.description: The bride and groom work for financial companies.

item.title: Faith Spencer, James Armstrong
item.description: The bride graduated from Sewanee: the University of the South, the groom from the University of South Carolina.

item.title: Candida Moss, Justin Foa
item.description: The couple met in 2015 through OkCupid.

item.title: Anna Ward, Daniel Frendl
item.description: The couple, both doctors, met in the pediatric operating room at Massachusetts General Hospital in the summer of 2016.

item.title: Anne Blackstock-Bernstein, Kyle Warren
item.description: Anne Blackstock-Bernstein and Kyle Warren were married April 7 at Cree Estate in Cathedral City, Calif., by the playwright Tony Kushner.

item.title: Delaney Simon, Graeme Smith
item.description: The couple met in 2015 Kabul during a meeting for political staff of the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan.

item.title: Lauren Attaway, Rogelio Thomas Jr.
item.description: The couple met at a bar in Manhattan in 2012.

item.title: Daniela Suarez, Sam Schatz
item.description: The bride and groom met on OkCupid and were married at the Marigny Opera House in New Orleans.
